description: A Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) is a probabilistic model that assumes all data points are generated from a mixture of several Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters. It is widely used for clustering and density estimation, allowing for the modeling of complex data distributions.

common_types.name: Full Covariance GMM
common_types.description: A model where each Gaussian component can have its own covariance matrix, allowing for flexible shapes of clusters, useful for modeling more complex distributions.

common_types.name: Diagonal Covariance GMM
common_types.description: A simplified model where each Gaussian component has a diagonal covariance matrix, which assumes that the features are independent, leading to simpler and faster computations.

common_types.name: Spherical Covariance GMM
common_types.description: A model where all Gaussian components are assumed to have the same spherical covariance matrix, leading to equally shaped clusters, often used for computational efficiency.

common_types.name: Tied Covariance GMM
common_types.description: A model where all components share the same covariance matrix, providing a balance between flexibility and complexity in modeling.

visualization_techniques.description: Displays the density of the mixture model, showing the regions of highest probability and the shape of the Gaussian components.
Visualizes the data points along with the Gaussian components, often showing the ellipses representing the covariance of each Gaussian cluster.
Represents the probability density function of the Gaussian mixture model in three dimensions, helping to visualize the clustering structure.
Illustrates the density of data points generated by the GMM, highlighting areas of high probability density.

applications: Image segmentation for separating objects in images based on color or intensity.
Anomaly detection in various fields by modeling the normal data distribution and identifying deviations.
Speech recognition for modeling the distribution of audio features in different phonemes.
Financial modeling to analyze asset returns, considering multiple sources of uncertainty.
